717894f-a.text:
Holland Tunnel Entrance (580) and 578 to 570 Broom Street, north side, between Hudson and Varick Streets. The tunnel has not quite yet been opened to the public. No 570 is the Roman Catholic Church of our Lady of Vilna. No 574 is the Duane Methodist Episcopal Church, which settled down at this address late in 1929. The old church (about 1862), at 292 Hudson Street, one the east side, south of Spring Street was demolished in 1923 (see Hudson Street). Originally the church was on Duane street, where it was established in 1797 and stood till destroyed by fire on 1861.
September 27, 1927
717894f-a.folder: Broome Street & Hudson Street, Manhattan, NY

717892f-a.text:
Holland Tunnel Plaza and Broome Street, north side, from No. 582 Broome, east of Hudson, to Clark Street (Sixth .venue Extension).
October 11,1928.
P. L. Sperr.
717892f-a.folder: Broome Street & Hudson Street, Manhattan, NY

717893f-a.text:
Entrance to the Holland Vehicular Tunnel, site of 578-582 Broome Street,north side, east of Hudson Street, showing four policemen and a toll collector keeping order as pleasure cars take the plunge into the tile lined tunnel, nearly a mile long. The office at the right is trying to look severe and dignified, mush to the amusement of the one in the right rear of the group.
Summer 1928

720508f-a.text:
250 Hudson Street, at the N.E. corner of Broome Street, as seen through
clearance from Renwick Street.
July 26, 1935.
P. L. Sporr.

720491f-a.text:
Hudson Street, east side, from Broome Street to Vestry, showi the new Holland Plaza Building in the block bounded by at
Hudson, Canal and Varick Streets.
November 6, 1929.
Brown Brothers.
